Author: Ezra

Author: Nehemiah

Author: various authors, but many attributed to David
Context: a collection of 150 songs that Israel sang to God (and to each other)

Author: Solomon and other wise men
Context: a collection of sayings written to help people make wise decisions that bring about justice.

Author: traditionally said to be Solomon
Context: a philosophical exploration of the meaning of life

Author: traditionally said to be Solomon
Context: a love song (or collection of love songs) celebrating love, desire, and marriage.

Author: Isaiah
Context: God sending the prophet Isaiah to warn Israel of future judgment—but also to tell them about a coming king and servant who will “bear the sins of many.”

Author: Jeremiah
Context: God sending a prophet to warn Israel about the coming Babylonian captivity, but the people don’t take the news very well.

Author: traditionally said to be Jeremiah
Context: a collection of dirges lamenting the fall of Jerusalem after the Babylonian attacks.

Author: Ezekiel
Context: God choosing a man to speak for Him to Israel, to tell them the error of their ways and teach them justice.

Author: Daniel (with other contributors)
Context: Daniel becoming a high-ranking wise man in the Babylonian and Persian empires, and has prophetic visions concerning Israel’s future.

Author: Hosea
Context: Hosea being told to marry a prostitute who leaves him, and he must bring her back: a picture of God’s relationship with Israel.

Author: Joel
Context: God sending a plague of locusts to judge Israel, but His judgment on the surrounding nations is coming, too.

Author: Amos
Context: a shepherd named Amos preaching against the injustice of the Northern Kingdom of Israel.

Author: Obadiah
Context: Obadiah warning the neighboring nation of Edom that they will be judged for plundering Jerusalem.

Author: traditionally said to be Jonah
Context: a disobedient prophet runnning from God, being swallowed by a great fish, and then preaching God’s message to the city of Nineveh.

Author: Micah
Context: Micah confronting the leaders of Israel and Judah regarding their injustice, and prophesies that one day the Lord Himself will rule in perfect justice.

Author: Nahum
Context: Nahum foretelling of God’s judgment on Nineveh, the capital of Assyria.

Author: Habakkuk
Context: Habakkuk pleading with God to stop the injustice and violence in Judah, and finding that God will use the even more violent Babylonians to do so.

Author: Zephaniah
Context: God warning that He will judge Israel and the surrounding nations, but also that He will restore them in peace and justice.

Author: Haggai
Context: the people having abandoned the work of restoring God’s temple in Jerusalem, and so Haggai takes them to task.

Author: Zechariah
Context: the prophet Zechariah calling upon Israel to return to God, and recording prophetic visions that show what’s happening behind the scenes.

Author: Malachi
Context: God being faithful to Israel, but they continued to live disconnected from Him—so God sends Malachi to call them out.

Author: Matthew
Context: an account of Jesus’ life, death, and resurrection, focusing on Jesus’ role as the true king of the Jews.

Author: John Mark
Context: an account of Jesus’ earthly ministry highlights Jesus’ authority and servanthood.

Author: Luke
Context: a most thorough account of Jesus’ life, pulling together eyewitness testimonies to tell the full story of Jesus as the Son of Man.

Author: John
Context: an account of signs and miracles with the hope that readers will believe Jesus is Christ and truly the Son of God.

Author: Paul

Author: Paul
Context: Paul instructing the Thessalonians on how to stand firm until the coming of Jesus.

Author: Paul
Context: Paul giving his protegé Timothy instruction on how to lead a church with sound teaching and a godly example.

Author: Paul
Context: Paul nearing the end of his life, and encouraging Timothy to continue preaching the word.

Author: Paul
